Universal Basic Income (UBI) is a policy proposal in which every adult (or every citizen/resident) receives a regular, unconditional cash payment sufficient to cover basic needs, regardless of employment status or income. Below is an overview:

1. Definition and Core Features  
 • Universal: paid to all individuals (sometimes only adults).  
 • Basic: set at a level intended to meet minimum living standards (not necessarily full subsistence).  
 • Income: cash payments, not in-kind benefits.  
 • Unconditional: no means-testing or work requirements.

2. Rationale  
 • Poverty alleviation: guarantees a safety net that prevents extreme hardship.  
 • Automation & job loss: buffers workers displaced by technological change.  
 • Simplification: consolidates or replaces complex welfare programs, reducing administrative overhead.  
 • Freedom and dignity: gives people autonomy to choose work, education, caregiving or entrepreneurship.

3. Funding Models  
 • Tax-based: financed by higher income, wealth, consumption or carbon taxes.  
 • Dividend-based: funded by revenues from natural resources or sovereign wealth funds.  
 • Consolidation: replacing targeted transfers (unemployment insurance, child benefits) with a single universal payment.  
 • Deficit-financed: short-term borrowing, ideally accompanied by medium-term tax reforms.

4. Variants and Design Choices  
 • Full UBI vs. partial/basic income guarantee (BIG): full covers basic needs; partial supplements existing income.  
 • Universal vs. selective: true universal vs. a “quasi-UBI” targeted to low-income households.  
 • Individual vs. household: paid per person or per household unit.  
 • Flat vs. progressive: flat amount for all or tapering with income.

5. Examples and Pilots  
 • Alaska Permanent Fund (since 1982): annual dividends (~US$1,000–2,000) to all residents from oil revenues.  
 • Finland (2017–18): 560 € monthly to 2,000 unemployed adults; improved well-being but no significant employment gains.  
 • Ontario, Canada (2017–18): CAD 17,000/year adults pilot; cancelled early.  
 • Kenya (ongoing): GiveDirectly trials in rural villages, positive effects on health, education and economic activity.  
 • Spain (2020): “Minimum Vital Income” targeted scheme for poorest households (€462–1,015/month).

6. Arguments For  
 • Poverty reduction: direct, predictable support.  
 • Administrative simplicity: replaces complex means-testing.  
 • Encourages risk-taking: people can pursue education, start businesses, change jobs.  
 • Social cohesion: reduces stigma of welfare recipiency.

7. Arguments Against  
 • Cost: universal payments can be very expensive (potentially 10–20% of GDP).  
 • Work disincentive: critics fear people may reduce labor supply (though evidence is mixed).  
 • Inflation risk: sudden increases in disposable income could push up prices in tight markets.  
 • Equity concerns: giving money to wealthy individuals may be seen as wasteful.

8. Key Implementation Challenges  
 • Determining the “right” level: balancing adequacy and affordability.  
 • Tax reform: aligning revenue-raising without excessive economic drag.  
 • Political feasibility: building broad support across the income spectrum.  
 • Integration with existing welfare: deciding which programs to keep, cut or merge.

9. Alternative or Complementary Policies  
 • Negative Income Tax (NIT): refundable tax credit that phases out as earnings rise.  
 • Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC): subsidizes low-wage work.  
 • Conditional cash transfers: require recipients to meet conditions (e.g., children’s school attendance).  
 • Job guarantees: government ensures employment at a living wage.

10. Conclusion  
UBI remains a lively and evolving policy debate. Pilot studies suggest positive impacts on well-being and entrepreneurial activity, with labor-supply effects smaller than feared. The main barriers are cost, political will and integration with existing social-protection systems. Countries with volatile natural-resource revenues or high inequality may find specially tailored UBI or partial-basic-income schemes especially attractive.
